question: The nurse is reviewing the client's electronic health record upon assuming care. The nurse is preparing to administer the 0900 medications. Click to highlight the order that requires immediate intervention by the nurse.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 07:30: Client is a 45-year-old with a history of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) admitted from the emergency department. Reports 3 days of 'flu-like symptoms' with nausea, vomiting, and profound weakness. States they 'ran out of hydrocortisone a week ago and had trouble with the pharmacy getting a refill approved.' Client is lethargic but oriented to person and place. Skin is cool, pale, with poor turgor. Abdomen is tender to palpation diffusely. Continuous cardiac monitoring initiated.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
• 07:30 (ED): T 38.5 C (101.3 F), HR 118 bpm, RR 22, BP 94/58 mmHg, SpO2 95% on room air.
  • 08:30 (ICU): T 38.7 C (101.7 F), HR 126 bpm, RR 24, BP 86/50 mmHg, SpO2 94% on room air.

tabs.title: Laboratory Results
tabs.content:
• Sodium: 128 mEq/L (Reference: 136-145 mEq/L)
  • Potassium: 6.8 mEq/L (Reference: 3.5-5.0 mEq/L)
  • Glucose, random: 58 mg/dL (Reference: 70-110 mg/dL)
  • BUN: 35 mg/dL (Reference: 10-20 mg/dL)
  • Creatinine: 1.5 mg/dL (Reference: 0.6-1.2 mg/dL)

tabs.title: Diagnostics
tabs.content: ECG Interpretation (08:45): Sinus tachycardia at 128 bpm. Presence of tall, peaked T-waves. PR interval slightly prolonged. QRS width is at the upper limit of normal. No acute ST changes.

tabs.title: Medication Administration Record
tabs.content:
Scheduled Medications @ 0900

  • Dextrose 5% in 0.9% Sodium Chloride (D5NS) continuous infusion at 250 mL/hr

  • Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV Push STAT (given at 08:35), now 50 mg IV every 6 hours

  • Ondansetron 4 mg IV every 6 hours PRN for nausea

  • Spironolactone 25 mg PO daily

rationale.correct: The combination of severe hyperkalemia (6.8 mEq/L) and its cardiotoxic effects (tall, peaked T-waves on ECG) represents a life-threatening emergency. Adrenal crisis is characterized by aldosterone deficiency, which causes the kidneys to retain potassium. Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and an aldosterone antagonist. Administering this medication would block any remaining aldosterone effect and further increase the serum potassium level, potentially precipitating ventricular fibrillation or asystole. This order is absolutely contraindicated and represents a critical safety risk. The nurse must withhold this medication, notify the provider immediately, and prepare for emergent treatment of hyperkalemia.
rationale.incorrect: The other orders are appropriate and indicated for the treatment of adrenal crisis. The client is hypotensive, hypovolemic, hyponatremic, and hypoglycemic. D5NS provides volume, sodium, and glucose to correct these imbalances. Hydrocortisone is the definitive treatment, replacing the deficient glucocorticoid and providing some mineralocorticoid effect. Ondansetron is appropriate for symptomatic treatment of nausea.

answerBreakdown.label: A
answerBreakdown.content: Dextrose 5% in 0.9% Sodium Chloride (D5NS) continuous infusion at 250 mL/hr
answerBreakdown.rationale: Incorrect. This is an appropriate and life-saving intervention. The client is in shock (hypotensive, tachycardic) and has hypoglycemia and hyponatremia. D5NS provides volume to treat shock, sodium to correct hyponatremia, and dextrose to correct hypoglycemia.

answerBreakdown.label: B
answerBreakdown.content: Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV Push STAT (given at 08:35), now 50 mg IV every 6 hours
answerBreakdown.rationale: Incorrect. This is the cornerstone of treatment for adrenal crisis. Replacing the deficient cortisol is essential to reverse the shock state and metabolic abnormalities. This is a priority medication to administer.

answerBreakdown.label: C
answerBreakdown.content: Ondansetron 4 mg IV every 6 hours PRN for nausea
answerBreakdown.rationale: Incorrect. This is an appropriate supportive care medication. Nausea and vomiting are classic symptoms of adrenal crisis, and treating them can prevent further fluid loss and improve client comfort.

answerBreakdown.label: D
answerBreakdown.rationale: Correct. This order is contraindicated and potentially lethal. The client has life-threatening hyperkalemia (K+ 6.8 mEq/L) with ECG changes. Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic. Administering it would worsen the hyperkalemia and increase the risk of fatal cardiac dysrhythmias.
